title: RL32914
content: Rising Navy ship procurement costs are a concern for Navy officials and Congress. The Congressional Budget Office estimates higher funding levels are needed for the Navy's shipbuilding plan. Congress must decide how to address these rising costs, which could impact Navy capabilities and the shipbuilding industry. Options include increasing funding and changing budgeting methods. Options for addressing rising Navy ship procurement costs include increasing funding, changing budgeting methods, utilizing multiyear procurement, altering acquisition strategies, reducing shipyard fixed overhead costs, improving yard efficiency, building ships without certain equipment, and considering foreign shipyards for construction. Another option is to shift to designs with lower unit procurement costs if other measures are insufficient. The report focuses on reducing Navy ship procurement costs by shifting to designs with lower unit procurement costs. It discusses background information on lower-cost options for attack submarines, aircraft carriers, and surface combatants, as well as potential advantages and disadvantages of this shift. Recent legislative activity related to rising Navy ship procurement costs is also reviewed. Lower-cost ship designs have been proposed in reports by the CBO, DOD's Office of Force Transformation, and the Center for Strategic and Budgetary Assessments. Options for lower-cost Navy ship designs can include reducing ship size, shifting from nuclear to conventional propulsion, and using hulls built to commercial-ship survivability standards. These changes can help reduce procurement costs significantly. Shifting from nuclear to conventional propulsion and using commercial-ship survivability standards for hulls can significantly reduce Navy ship procurement costs. Additionally, using a common hull design for multiple ship classes can further decrease costs by avoiding the need to design new hulls for each class. The Navy plans to use a common hull design for its DDG-1000 destroyer and CG(X) cruiser, as well as for other large surface ships. Lower-cost ship options using this approach will be less capable than current designs but can reduce procurement costs significantly. The potential advantages and disadvantages of shifting to lower-cost designs are discussed in the final section of the report.
